Scatterd along, can weake resistance make:
Plainenesse of ground affoording vs no shelter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For what serues Art and Engines, Mounts and Trenches,
But to correct the nature of a plaine?
A few on firme land may keepe out a million,
Weaken'd by sea, false footing, billowes rage,
And ponderous rage. When as receiu'd within,
He prospers by our spoile; We feed a Viper:
And male-contents and rebells haue a refuge.
Nor were it safe, to venter all at once:
When one fought field being lost, swift ruine runnes
And rushing throwes downe all.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: We know our strength, and his: wee'l fight in field.
Some dozen miles from sea. An open Theater
Giues luster to our prowesse: To keep him out
Supposes feare, not manhood. No, let him march,
Till he rowse death, and stride his future graue.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your will commands, and mine obeies. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 4.
div.stage: Caesar, &c. Ensigne, Drumme, Trumpet, Flag, Souldiers, Shipmen. The noyse of landing.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: The coast is cleere. Our honour is the Goale.
In vaine doth Tagus yellow sand obey,
Rhenes horned front, and nimble Tygris running
For wager with the wind, which skimmes his top:
In vaine from Ganges to Hesperian Gades,
The Bounds markt out by Ioues two base-borne Sonnes,
Our Ecchoed Name doth sound: If we recoyle
From hence againe not victours.
Ye Pilotes old, who were begot on mere-Maides,
Whose Element is the Sea, bred and brought vp
In cradles rockt with stormes, and woodden walles,
Feare not to grapple with their seas. Feare not
Their bulkes, Brave veteranes: That extended masse
Is not of iron, but can bleed, and dye:
They were not dipt in Styx: nor are they Gyants,
Or wild Poetick Centaures we assayle:
Let then this voyage quit our credit lost,
And let Rage lash on Courage. Heere's the Game:
Life may be lost, but sure weele hold fast Fame.

div.stage: They march about, and goe out. The whole battaile with-in.

sp.speaker: Gass.
sp.l: Our first attempt doth prosper: They retiring
Scudde to the bosome of their Firre-tree vaultes,
And vnder hatches hide themselues from death.
The Cornish band made havocke of their rankes,
Like Scythian wolues midst of a bleating fold:
The gingling launces, ratling chariot-wheeles
Madded their horse. The Bow men merrily shott.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yet would our tributary Kings had succoured!
We are decai'd they much in number growne,
And surely will make head againe.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: Feare not, thou knowest I can euen with a whistle,
Hide Kent with glittering armes: More flaming sparkles
Paint not a freezing night: nor speckled Bees
Buzze not about sweet Hyblaes bloomy head.
But what need millions, when some thousands serue?
O did my Brother liue! wee'de clime the Alpes;
Like braue Mulmutius sonnes; make Romulus woolfe
Howle horrour in their streets, and Rome looke pale,
As when the Punicke Captaine eyed her walles. march out.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Are ye the Men, who neuer fought in vaine?
Who weare Bellonaes fauours, in your skarres:
I, ye are They. What then benummes our Spirits?
Our Empire from Quirinus narrow Center
Doth circling spread, and finds no brinke nor bottome.
Titan no later sets, nor earlier wakes,
Than he beholds our Provinces, Why, then?
What Priviledge hath this place? Haue wee, or They
The Phrygian powers? Haue they Palladium got?
No, no, Those gods our Capitoll keepe with ioy:
These only haue vn-daunted minds from Troy.
What newes, good Atrius?

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: No good newes from Atrius.
When ominous Earth with shade and cloudy vapours
Had darknesse doubled, stormes began to sound,
The dabled South, ruffe-footed Aquilo,
Came rushing like two Rams, whose steeled hornes
Dart fiery sparkes: The clouds crusht breathe out flames:
Thunder and Lightning daunt all eares and eyes.
The windes and billowes striue, who loudest roare.
The skie distill'd in raine: his roome to fill,
Ambitious waues would clime the starry hill.
Our ships are batterd all, some fortie sunke.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: What diuell-Cacus drags our Fortune backe?
Doth Shee mooue retrograde? and hoyst vs vp.
That we may fall at heigth? Why doest Camillus
Each night torment my sleep, and cry, Reuenge?
I striue against the streame.

sp.speaker: Androg.
sp.l: Thus ioyne we Standards: And resigne the keies
Of Troynovant, with all our warlike forces.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: By me the Trinobants submit, and Cenimagnians,
Segontiackes, Ancalites, Bybrockes, and Cassians,
Sixe worthy nations doe desire thy guard.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: All, all shall know our loue.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: The Tyrant lies on Isis flowrie bankes,
Where a full Quier sing of white-surplist swannes.
The foordes vnleuell belly they haue fenced,
With sharpe stakes vnder water.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Nor stakes, lakes, foords, nor swords shall checke our progresse:
Those downie swannes shall heare more funerall notes.
Their Kings departed, Nennius dead, whose losse
Would teares extort euen from Pumicean eies;
Had Britaine nurst but such another Champion,
They might haue stucke their darts on our barr'd gates,
And Latium trembled with contrary fates.
In what now lies their hope?

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Great numbers still remaine: nay worse, they laugh
At death, and boldly trust (as Druids preach)
Their soules who die in fight shall liue in ioy.
Hence count they dangers, benefits: and die
With freedome in their mouth, and willfull rage.
But let soft mildnes waite on women, Let
Thy wrath ring through the woods in dustie noise,
To tell thy comming. No man's built so loftie,
But his foundation meetes the humble dust:
Which vndermin'd, how high he pearc'd the clouds,
So deep he sinkes.
Hostile and ciuill foes shake top and roote
As windes inuade aboue, and Vines below.
And so will We.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: No doubt: This blow shall like an earth-quake mooue
The rootes and pillars of this sea-clipt Ile.
A cloud of vultures shall attend our Campe,
And no more shall the fields beare Vert, but Gules:
The graine en-graind in purple die shall loose
His verdant hue. Bones, marrow, humane limbes
Shall putrifying reake, whose vapoured slime
Kindled on high may breed long-bearded Starres,
To tell more mischiefe, and out-beard Apollo.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Let's wast no time, least more vnto him flocke,
As humours glide to guard the wounded member.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Atrius, let our ships be drawne on shoare,
New-rigg'd and mended. I must needs confesse him
A darling of the gods; vnder whose colours
Starres, winter, skie, and tempests serue in pay,
And know both march and skirmish by his Drumme. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: O my deare Ladie, hast thou slaine thy selfe?
So fairely pure, so kindly chast, so cries.
A Venus and Diana mixt in one.
She eat her meate with studdes of Pearle, she kist
With Rubies, and she look't with Diamonds bright.
Fish seas, and foule the aire, hunt all the earth,
For such another bit, and loose your labour.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O, why dost thou complaine.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: Had she not kill'd her selfe, no cruell Atropos,
No fury could for pitty cut her thread.
She was the Load-stone of all eies, The whet-stone
Of all braines, the touch-stone of all hearts: She was— cries.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O my presaging thoughts in vgly forme
Suggest some Tragedy. Speake: yet stay a while:
I know thou kill'st with speaking. Be then dumbe:
Let sound neere giue those Notions airie roabes.
Yet speake, dispatch me: Feare's as bad as death.
Oh, could no tongue affirme it! Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: My Mistresse is.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVither ye pleasant gardens, where she trod:
VVhite lillyes droope, and blasted daysies winke,
And weep in pearely dew. Blind Vesper mourne,
Hang thy cold teares on euery grassie blade.
Groane loud ye woods, and teare your leafie haire:
Let wind and hoarie frost kill euery flower:
For she is gone, who made continuall May.
Let foggie mistes envellop Sunne and Starres:
For she is gone, who made perpetuall day.
Confounded Nature stand amaz'd, dissolue
Thy rowling engines, and vnbrace the Seas:
Fling all into their first disordered lumpe.
For thy chiefe paragon, thy rich Master-piece,
The Iewell, for which thou didst venter all,
Is lost, is lost. And can I liue to speake it?
How died she?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: By a poisoned draught.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: The very word (poison) infects my breath.
Durst thou presume to passe that corrall portch?
Were not her Lippes sufficient Antidote?
Durst thou descend through those close winding staires
With treacherous intent? How could thy venome
Seaze on her, and not sweetned loose his vertue,
Or rather vitious qualitie? May toades,
Dragons, and mandrakes be thy gally-pottes:
This Bodie was a casket for the graces,
No caske for poison. With her dies all loue:
Cupid may breake his Bow, his arrowes burne,
Then quench his Taper in a flood of teares.
Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: Or in a long traunce.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: She may reuiue:
I'le visit her: Art may prolong her daies,
Whether she will or no.— Exeunt.

lg.l: With knotty bunch of curled snakes,
More ghastly monster did not spring,
Shall no more Shepheards in the shade
Shall neuer speare be made a spade,
Grant heauen at last, that Musick loud
That Britaine Virgins in a croud,
With hymnes the skie may fill.
The least part of our mournefull muse:
This Troiane Dame for Bride did chuse.
Law to deuise. O sound Landor. praise.
Cleare as great Deliaes horned bow,
Bright as the Queene of Loue,
To shoote downe gentle beames below.
A gem her eie: O sound Lando. praise.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Thus gaine we ground: yet still our foes will fight,
Whether they winne or loose. With bloody drops
Our path is printed: Thames his maiden-cheekes
Blush with vermilion: Nations crave our League
On euery side: Yet still Cassibelane braves vs,
Nor will submit.

sp.speaker: Androg.
sp.l: Not farre hence Verolame lies, his chiefest fort,
By nature guarded round with woods and fennes,
By Art enclosed with a ditch and rampire:
From hence we must dislodge the Boare.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: There are but two wayes to assayle this Towne:
Both which I know. Your parted army must
Breake thorow both at once, and so distract
His doubtfull reskues.

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: Draw slaves vnwilling, I dare meete my death:
And lead my Leader.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: You'le repent anon,

sp.speaker: Hal
sp.l: If I doe ill: But not for suffering ill.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Your stoicall apathy will relent I know.
This Priest I caught within a shady grove,
Devoutly kneeling at a broad Okes foot.
Now He awaites your Doome.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: What god adore you?

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: Him, whom all should serue.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Whats the Moone?

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: Nights Sunne:

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Whats Night?

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: A foyle to glorifie the Day.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: What most compendious way to happinesse?

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: To dye in a good cause.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: What is a man?

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: An Hermaphrodite of soule & body.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: How differ they in nature?

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: The body hath in waight, the soule in length.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: One question more: What dangers shall I passe?

sp.speaker: Hul.
sp.l: Many by land and sea: As steps to glory▪
Throw Palatine on Aesquiline, on both
Heape Aventine, to raise one Pyramis: for a
Chaire of Estate, where thy aduanced Head
Among those Heroes pictur'd in the Starres,
Orion, Perseus, Hercules, may consult
With Iove himselfe. But shun the Senate house.
March round about the Caspian sea; search out
'Mong Cedars tall the Arabian Phaenix nest;
Run counter to old Nile, till thou discouer
His sacred head wrapt vp in cloudy mountaines:
And rather than worke fayle, Turne Hellespont
Out of his channell; Digge that Isthmus downe,
Which tyes great Africk. Shun the Senate house.
Be Saturne, and so thou shalt not be Tarquine.
A Brutus strong,
Repayes in Fine:
Thy brutish wrong
To Brutus line.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Wee'll talke at leasure more. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: No rampires keepe him backe: He presses forward,
Though euery stampe he treads, seemes to coniure
The fates from their infernall center. None
But he, durst be so bold.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, when Britaines lead, and Mandubrace insulting
With naked sword calles on the lagging souldiers:
When fearce Androgeus with revolted nations,
Vsher his army. No way halfe so quicke
To ruinate kingdomes, as by home-bred strife.
Thus while we single fight, we perish all.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: I, I, those treacherous caitiffes, rebell slaves:
O may their countryes heauy curse them sinke
Below the nine-fold brazen gates of hell:
That princox proud: I, twas a scape in policy,
I should haue slaine the whelps with their good Syre.
Let Britaines climactericall yeere now runne,
The Series breake of seuentie Kings: Nay let
One vrne conclude our ashes and the worlds.
Befall what will: In midst of horrors noyse,
And crackling flames, when all is lost, wee'll dye
With weapons in our hands, and victory skorne:
There's none that dye so poore, as they are borne.
Faithfull Belinus, let a Post command
The Kentish Kings to set vpon his fleete:
Whilst we heere bid the bace. Foure thousand chariotteers,
(Such as did glide vpon the Phrygian Plaines,
And wheeling double seruice doe performe,
Both horse-mans speed, and foot-mans stable strength)
Still doe remaine: With these and flocking voluntaries
Wee'll giue him once more battell. Let the Captaines
Enter, and heare my charge. Enter Captaines. He stands on a throne.
Subiects and Fellow-souldiers; We must now try
For ancient freedome, or perpetuall bondage.
There is no third choise. The inraged foe
With cruell pride, proud avarice, hath spoyl'd
From East to West, hunting for blood and gaine.
Your wiues and daughters ravisht, ransackt townes,
Great bellyes ript with launces, sprawling babes,
The spouse about her husbands necke run through
By the same speare. Thinke on these Obiects:
Then choose them for your Lords, who spoyle and burne
Whole countryes; and call Desolation, Peace.
Yeeld, yeeld; That he ennobled by our spoyles,
May clime the Capitoll with triumphant carte,
You led fast fetterd through the staring streets,
For citie Dames to mocke your habite strange,
And fill their arras hangings with our story.
No: Brennus ghost forbid, who this night stood,
Before my eyes, and grimly furious spake:
Shall Britaine stoop to Romane Rods and Hatchets,
And servile tribute? Will ye so defame
Your ancestors, and your successors wrong,
Heires but of slauery▪ O, this day make good
The glory of so many ages past!
I see, you are incens'd, and wish to vse
Your weapons, not your eares.
All. To armes, to armes, to armes: Wee'll fight, and dye.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 3.
div.stage: Eulinus, in a nightcap. vnbraced. Violl. Poynado. Playes and sings to the violl.
div.l: So the Siluer-feathered swan,
Both by death and colour wan,
Loues to sing before shee dye,
Leauing life so willingly.
But how can I sing a note?
When dead hoarsenesse stops my throat:
Or how can I play a stroke?
When my heart-strings all are broke.
Come guilty night, and with blacke velvet wings
Mantle me round; Let melancholike thoughts,
Hang all my braine with Blacks: This darkesome grove,
My gallery. So, all things suite my mind:
Such funerall colours please a gasping heart.
I dyed with thee Landora once: Now only
Some strugling spirits are behind, to be
Laid out with most thrift on thy memory.
Where shall I first begin my last complaint,
Which must be measur'd by my glasse of life?
At thee Hirildas? Slaine in furious moode,
By whose helpe only I inioy'd my loue?
Or thee Landora? dying for his sake,
And in thy death including mine?
Or at my Countries wracke? whose surface torne
Doth for my vengeance importune the Pole?
Or at my selfe? I, there is sorrowes spring.
Shall I goe wandring lurke in woods vnknowne,
A banisht Hermite, and sigh out my griefes?
Teaching the prettie birds to sing my deare,
My deare Landora: There to feed on acornes,
Drinke the cleare fountaine, and consume with weeping,
Were but an easie life, an easie death:
My violent passion must haue sudden vent.
Refined Soule, whose odoriferous light,
The damned hags stare at, and whining elves,
Thinking it Heauen in hell: Behold my pangs,
Pittie my dying groanes, and be more soft.
O may our shadowes mingle; then shall I
Enuie no more those Citizens aboue,
The ambrosian iuncates of the Olympian hall
And all that gorgeous Roofe. But cowards talke.
Come thou last refuge of a wearisome life; Drawes his Poynado.
A pasport to the Elysian land, A key
To vnlocke my grieued in-mate. Loe I come.
O let this riuer from my eyes, this streame vnbuttons.
From my poore breast, beg fauour of thy ghost:
O let this luke-warme blood thy Rigour steepe, stabs.
And mollifie thy adamantine heart.
Leander-like I swim to thee through blood:
Be thy bright eyes my Pharos, and conduct me
Through the dull night of gloomy Erebus.
Flow, flow, ye liuely drops, and from my veines
Run winding to the Ocean of my blisse:
Tell her my loue, and if Shee still shall doubt,
Sweare that ye came directly from my heart.
I stay too long. stabs agen. Sweet Lady giue me wellcome.
Though I shall passe twelue monsters as the Sunne,
Or twelue Herculean labours on a row:
Yet one kinde looke makes all my iourney sweet
Thou Fayry-Queene of the Tartarian Court,
To whom Proserpine may the Apple giue,
Worthier than Shee, to warme old Plutoes bed:
See thy poore vassall weltering in his goare.
I faint, I faint.
I dye thy Martyr, as I liu'd thy Priest:
Great Goddesse be propitious, Sweet Landora —

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 4.
div.stage: The foure Kings of Kent march ouer the stage. A Drum strucke vp within. Q. Atrius comes with Cingetorix prisoner. Rollano running. Volusene meetes him.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: What shall I doee? How shall I scape? falls for feare.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I scorne to take aduantage, Rise and Fight.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: I had rather be kill'd quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Then die, as thou destrest. thrusts at him.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: O let me winke first. bawles aloud.
I shall neuer indure it. Oh, oh. I am pepper'd and salted.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: O that base Fortune should great spirits damp,
And fawne on muddie slaues: That enuious fate
Should ripen villany with a Syrian dew,
And blast sweet vertue with a Sirian flame.
A Catalogue of mischiefes doe concurre
Our Britaine Hector, Nennius dead: Our Kings
Angry to be refus'd, sit stil at home:
And then those traitors with their traine augment
His huge and expert Armie: Nothing stops him;
Riuers, nor Rampiers, Woods, nor dangerous Bogges;
On this side Thames his dismall Ensignes shine:
Last, Kents vnhappie rulers are at Sea
Ore-throwne, and our men almost spent. Then, Generall,
In desperate pride, and valours scornefull rage,
Let vs runne head-long through their armed tents,
And make their Campe a Shambles: So to raise
Our loftie toombes vpon their slaughtered heapes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay, rather first lets parley for peace.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: Ye Country-gods and Nymphes, who Albion loue,
Old Father Neptune, all ye powers diuine,
Witnesse my loyall care: If humane strength,
Courage, and policy, could a Kingdome saue;
We did our best. But discord, child of hell,
Numbers of traine-men, and each Captaine pickt
Out of a Province, make vs bow or breake.
In vaine we striue, when Deities doe frowne:
When Destinies push, Atlas himselfe comes downe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No mediator is so fit as Comius: And heer's the man.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Doe not the dangers which enuiron you,
Call for a good conclusion? which I wish
As friend to both sides.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: No Comius: There is more behind, than Caesar
Hath ouer-runne: Our Chariotters still driue,
Our harnesse still is worne: Through woods and lakes
Wee'l tire his daintie souldiers: Then set fire
On Townes, and sacrifice our selues, our wiues,
Our goods, and cattell, in one publike flame:
That wind may blow our ashes in his face.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: So shall dead Elements curse your causelesse fury.
Rather conclude some friendly peace.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: Thus farre we heare you: If with honoured termes,
And royall lookes, he will accept our faith:
We will obey, but neuer serue.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I'le vndertake as much. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Thus ciuill warre by me, and factious broyles,
Deface this goodly land: I am reueng'd:
The cause Eulinus dead, my Anger dies.
He is our Vncle, and in danger's mouth;
Both claime relenting pitty. Whom peace made
A rampant Lyon, warre hath made a Lambe.
Caesar shall not proceede, for priuate ends,
To captiuate our Ile: whose clamorous curse
Doth knock, I know, at Heauens Starre-nailed gates:
For that Ioues bird, impt with our plumes, ore-flew
The Oceans wall; To seeke her prey in Britaine.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: I, we haue made a Rod for our owne backes:
Fetters of gold are fetters. No gap worse
To let destruction in by, than to call
A forraine aide: who hauing seene our weaknesse,
And tasted once the fatnesse of our land,
Is not so easily thrust out, as admitted.
Such medicine is worse than the maladie,
Fretting the bowells of our kingdome.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I know their hatred iust; and heere resigne
All my birth-right to thee, my second selfe:
I must forsake my Countries sight, and seeke
New fortunes with this Emperour; In hope
To be rais'd vp, by his now rising wheele.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: O, doe not so, deare Brother. So to part,
Were to diuide one Indiuiduall Soule.
Nor thinke me so ambitious: I can liue
A priuate life, and see a regall Crowne,
With no more entry than I see the Sunne,
Glitter aboue me. Let not Lud's two sonnes
Be parted by a Sea: I hold your presence,
At higher price than a whole kingdomes pomp.
Keepe then your right: like those admired twinnes,
Let vs reioyce, mourne, liue, and die together.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: You shall a Scepter gaine.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: And loose a Brother.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Beare you the Soueraigne power of this land.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: A body politicke must on two legges stand:
I'le beare a part, so to diminish enuy.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I must away, and shun the peoples eie.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: If to your selfe vnkind, be kind to me:
For my sake stay at home: why will you flie?
Thinke you a stepdame soile giues sweeter sappe?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I: For trees transplanted do more goodly grow.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: And I'le count men but stockes, when they do so.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I am resolu'd: All troubles brought a sleepe:
To leaue you with a parting kisse.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: And by that kisse
May I transfuse my soule, or quite expire?
Brothers haue often for a kingdome fought:
We striue to loose it. This is holy strife.
But heere I vow, if ere that sacred Lace
Shall gird my Temples: Rome must keep her boundes,
Or fish for Tribute in the dredfull deepe.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 6.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Let gracious fauour smooth warres rugged brow:
Cassibelane will compound: All rage must end:
We choose you Vmpire, for a friendly cloze.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: It is my glory to end all with peace:
And for that cause, I Comius sent in hast,
For to conduct him hither.

sp.speaker: Them.
sp.l: This trump giues warning of the Kings approach.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: Fate, and no fault of mine, makes me appeare,
To yeeld as far as honour giues me leaue.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Haile valorous prince, disdaine not this ingrafting
Into Romes Empire, whose command incloses
The whole Leuant, and whose large shadow hides
The triple-bounded Earth, and bellowing Seas.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: We shall obserue your will; so you impose
A league, no yoake. They shake hands.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Thus we determine: That Crowne still shall stand;
Raigne as the totall Monarch of this Ile:
Till death vn-kings you. 'Twere, Androgeus, best
You in our traine kept honourable place:
And let Themantius weare the royall wreath.
You must forgiue the Townes which did reuolt,
Nor seeke reuenge on Trinobants, but let
Young Mandubrace possesse his Fathers Princedome.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: Be all wrongs drencht in Lethe.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Pardon my rash attempts. Cassib. embraces Androg. and Mand.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Count me your loyall friend.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: In signe of league, you shall vs pledges giue,
And yeerely pay three thousand pound of siluer,
Vnto our Treasury. So let these decrees
Be straight proclaim'd through Troynovant, whose Tower
Shall be more fairely built at my charge, as
A lasting Monument of our arriuall.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: All shall be done: Renowned Prince, whose worth,
Vnparalelld both as a Friend and Foe,
We doe admire.
Accept this Surcoate, starrified with pearles,
And Diamonds, such as our owne shoares breed.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: And you receiue this massie Cup of gold,
Loues earnest, and Memoriall of this day:
By this, suppose our Senate cals you friend.

sp.speaker: Lant.
sp.l: Now time, best Oracle of Oracles,
Father of truth, the true sense doth suggest
Of Dians answer;
The Lyon and the Eagle doe designe
The Britaine and the Romane states, whose armes
Were painted with those Animals: Both fierce
Weary at last conclude: The Semicircles,
First letters of the Leaders names, we see
Are ioyn'd in true loues endlesse figure.
Both come of Troiane race, both nobly bold,
Both matchlesse Captaines, on one Throne behold.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Now the Tarpeyan rocke ore-lookes the world;
Her Empire bounded onely by the Ocean;
And boundlesse Fame beates on the starry Pole.
So Danow crawling from a mountaines side,
Wider and deeper growes, and like a Serpent,
Or Pyramis reuerst; improues his bignesse,
As well as length: Till viewing countries large,
And fed with sixty riuers, his wide mouth
On the Euxine Sea-nymph gapes, and feare doth stir,
Whether he will disgorge, or swallow her.

sp.speaker: Cassib.
sp.l: Since the great guide of all, Olympus King,
Will haue the Romanes his Vice-Royes on earth:
Since the red fatall eyes of crow-blacke night,
Fling their malignant influence on our state:
Since Britaine must submit: It was her fame,
None but a Iulius Caesar could her tame.

div.stage: While Trumpets sound: Androgeus and Themantius imbracing take leaue. All depart.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 7. Chorus.

lg.l: Come fellow Bards and sing with cheere;
Since dreadfull Alarums we shall no more heare.
Come louely peace, our Saint diuine,
Oliue and Lawrell doe loue for to twine.
The Graces, and Muses, and Nymphes in a round:
Let voice beate the aire, and feet beat the ground.
So Hells blacke image chas'd away,
Eos doth dandle the goldy-lock'd day:
Cupid and Flora the spring doe adorne.
And so the grim fury of Mars laid in graue,
A merrier ending doth friendly peace craue.

lg.head: 2. Song. A Morisko.
lg.l: The Skie is glad that Starres aboue,
The Starres vnfold their flaming gold,
To make the ground more tender:
The ground doth send a fragrant smell,
That aire may be the sweeter:
The aire doth charme the swelling Seas,
The Sea with rivers water doth
The plants doe yeeld their fruitfull seed,
That beasts may liue in plenty:
The Beasts doe giue both food and cloth,
That man high Ioue may honour:
And so the world runnes merrily round,
When peace doth smile vpon her.
Oh then, then Oh: Oh then, then Oh:
That Forraine spight, or Ciuill fight,

div.stage: Mercury reducing the Ghostes of Camillus, and Brennus.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How brauely Caesar past the angry Maine?

sp.speaker: Brenn.
sp.l: How brauely was he backe repulst againe?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How did he wheele his sword in Nennius face?

sp.speaker: Brenn.
sp.l: How did he loose his sword, and flie apace?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How did againe his Army fill your coast?

sp.speaker: Brenn.
sp.l: I, when our Princes did conduct his hoast.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How did they pierce through Isis dangerous flood?

sp.speaker: Brenn.
sp.l: But made her swell, and bank-rupt with their blood.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Mirrour of Captaines, Iulius stile hath wonne.

sp.speaker: Brenn.
sp.l: But we may iustly brag of two for one.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Confesse, our valorous race hath now repaid
The Allian Massacre, and our cities Flame:
See how they yeeld, and yeerely Tribute pay.

sp.speaker: Brenn.
sp.l: No, proud Dictator: Both do weary stand
On equall termes: Both wish a peacefull League.
But if they shall oppresse; know, Generous spirits
Will breake this Compact, like a Spiders webbe.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Ioues will is finisht: And (though Iuno frowne,
That no more Troiane blood shall die the stage)
The worlds fourth Empire Britaine doth embrace.
The Thunder-bearer with a Ianus looke
At once viewes ruddie morne, and cloudie West:
Her wings displaied ore this Terrestriall egge,
Will shortly hatch an Vniuersall peace:
For Ioue intends a fauour to the world.
It now remaines, That you two martiall wights
Cease from your brauing one anothers worth:
You must be friends at last. The cloze is sweete,
When after tumults, hearts and hands doe meete.

q.l: Nec Lusisse pudet, sed non incidere Ludum.
